ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An understanding of calculus in 3 dimensions, an expanded skillset in math operations and reasoning, and a strong foundation in more general calculus.
I expanded my knowledge of calculus, particularly into problems involving functions of two or more variables. I also learned about three and four dimensional geometry.
a broad, computational understanding of multivariable calculus

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Homework is generally very manageable (time- and difficulty-wise) and is a good review of material and practice of skills. Lessons are helpful, go at a moderate pace, and are full of examples. More in-depth explanation could be nice (sometimes the concepts are diluted and simplified for us), but overall a good course that teaches you 3D calc very well.
Teacher wasn't that engaging, and I relied on other people's notes.
Ximera is a great resource for this class. However, in class there could be more thorough explanations for how to solve specific types of problems.

the course moved very fast, and i often found myself frantically taking notes during lecture, then having to relearn the material after lecture. because there is just so much material to cover, i think this was just the nature of the course  it's hard to say how it could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Anyone who wants to learn multivariable calculus should take this course. It teaches you the skills, gives a good understanding, and is a pleasant course (in terms of structure and difficulty).
If the student was interested in taking mathematics or other applied sciences that require multi variable calculus, yes. Otherwise, no.

neutral  i think, if you need / want to learn multivariable calculus (esp. if, like me, you've never had exposure to it before), this is what you've got to do. there were certainly points where i felt very, very confused, but you must overcome that stage of confusion to reach a stage of understanding.
